Mates,
I will be in front of Judge Diamond and defense has offered to split the stip values with me, the 39 (counting the apportionment) versus the 52 the DEU rated, but stated "before apportionment" Tis issue comes down to whether the alleged second DOI(2018) is the cause of my clients left knee disability or it was a compensable consequence from the accepted June 2017 injury where she was hit in the back by a pallet and then had an altered gate while she continued to work for another 6 months.
Excerpt from his discussion of the left knee injury regarding causation.
"During the previous evaluation she stated that the pain in the left
knee occurred in a separate injury at work which she thought had happened in June of 2018 approximately 6 months following the 12/08/17 injury, but she was not sure if it may have been related to the incident involving the forklift. This could only be determined with a more complete study of any medical records that may shed more light on the left knee injury. To date no such records have been reviewed. Therefore it is my opinion that the present impairment to the left knee is related to a compensable consequence of the 12/08/17 specific injury and the 12/11/18 unreported injury. It is also within reasonable medical probability that the applicant will need a total left knee arthroplasty in the future."
We go to a depo to clarify but Dr. Owen flips flops at the depo giving defense what they want and then I clarify there was no other event or trauma that cause the left knee disability and he then agrees with me.
I'm inclined to proceed with trial because there is no evidence to base a causation or apportionment of the left knee disability to create a substantial opinion. To me it is all conjecture and speculation.
Can Judge Diamond parse through this? Is there any bias of not liking compensable consequence injuries I need to be aware of?
TYIA for the feedback.

Ken – thanks. Jamie Blunt and Heather Harper were also kind enough to send me copies. That case stands for penalties for delay when QME requested diagnostics were delayed (70 days in that case) in a denied case. Confirming 4600 duty to provide medical care, 10109 duty to investigate. Great case.

ART – in the greater East LA area, the ORTHO (MOS) QME pools generally yield a washout. Why do that?
For a serous post-surgical case, both PMR and MPA are my go-to’s. They both will refer out to other specialties and provide pretty generous future medical treatment recommendations. For a pre-surgical, I would do a DCH if spine was a claimed body part. In my experience the DCH are actually the best at giving the “most accurate” (i.e., highest) impairment per the AMA guides. However, a number of WCJ’s are irrationally biased against DCH QME’s and carriers will pretend that a DCH QME isn’t as good as a QME from an MD.
Bret Graham, Esq.
Nava Graham Montebello

Montebello, CA 90640
